displayed_text: Patient: One slot. Okay. So, if it is filled by the end of next week. Let’s say I, uh, decide not to, uh, take it. Um. Doctor: That person has to be on treatment for a month. And then they -- Patient: December. Doctor: Then they can decide that there’s now three more spots, you know. Patient: It would be six more slots in group three. It says, “Six cohorts groups of up to six subjects.” Doctor: Right. So, they do three. And if any of them have a bad side effect, they have three more. Patient: Oh. Doctor: That’s where the cohorts come up to six. Patient: Come up to six. Okay. So, so, it can - alright. Doctor: I’m willing to accept one out of three people having trouble. Um. And so, if we see one out of three, we don’t know whether it is actually more, so we add six. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: So, if two out of six get into trouble, then we stop. Patient: Okay.

Patient: That’s fine. Doctor: No pain? Patient: I don’t even get the pain when I’m sitting around the house. Doctor: Really? Patient: When I go to sleep at night… Doctor: Okay, maybe it’s not that bad. Okay, push down on mine. Push, push, push. Patient: Push, just push Doctor: Yes. Pull up towards me. (Paper rattling and thumping) Patient: Yeah, no, like I said, at work, I don’t have any problem with walking around, but since, I say, I noticed that I was gettin’ that pain, and it was startin’ to become an irritant to me where I used to didn’t have that problem. You know? Doctor: Now, are you using anything for pain? Patient: No. I didn’t want to do that until I talked to you. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to give you a prescription? Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me?

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Who become resistant to hormones. Patient: Yeah, you talked about that. Doctor: And one of the things we’re observing is men who have BRCA2 mutation seem to respond really well to getting testosterone. We’re trying to figure out why. We just put in a big grant to kind of study this. So, so, we are about to, uh, have some trials where we’re – one of our trials is, if a guy has a mutation in this and he maybe responds to testosterone and he maybe responds to immune therapy, what if we give him both? Um. So, that’s a trial down the road that’s going to open up, um, probably in the next six months. We can talk more about that. Patient: If you get the grant? Doctor: No, we got that already. Patient: Oh. Doctor: We made a deal with one of the drug companies who makes the immune therapy. Family Member: Well, they are good for something. Doctor: So, my advice right now, we don’t do anything. You’re responding to hormone treatment. Let’s keep going. And, at some point, we don’t know if this has anything to do with BRCA2 or whatever, but at some point, you’re going to become resistant. Everybody does. And, at that point, we, we will discuss what to do next. And, normally, Patient: So --- Doctor: What to do next – I’m sorry – is to give you another hormone therapy. But, in your case, what, what we might do next is consider like, a trial where we use one of these DNA repair blockers. Um. And, we have two of them open right now that you would be eligible for. So. So, you know, the issue with you is I don’t want to talk about those yet because you might respond to hormone therapy for five more years. (laughs) Patient: Yeah. It, it was two hundred and fifty dollars.

Patient: Yeah. I’m taking her to lunch. Doctor: That’s nice. Where you guys going? Patient: Downtown somewhere. Doctor: Oh. Did you check out the, the, S___ S___? Do you guys ever go in there? Family Member: No. Doctor: It’s really good. Family Member: Oh. Sounds interesting. Doctor: It’s, it’s, you know, on one of those Zagat books and stuff. Family Member: Right. Doctor: It’s just, they do creative things. It’s not your standard mac and cheese. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: You like it?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh You’d think it was a full moon today, crazy things are happening. (pause10sec) Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh no new allergies? Patient: No. Doctor: So you’re taking Napercin or Patient: For the nerves. Doctor: Napercin is a – for – like Ibuprofen uh like you had something for your bathroom Patient: That - That was a long time ago. Patient: Yes. Yep. Doctor: And atorvastatin forty milligrams times a day? Patient: Yep.

Patient: The nurse, his nurse is mailing me the paper forms, but I will, I’m just going to tell M_ when I walk up in here. Because then it shows right up in my record; you guys have it in a day or two. Doctor: Yep. Patient: I don’t have to deal with one extra fax. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And all that. Doctor: So, April seventeenth for me and then come in any time before that for PSA. Family Member: Like by the tenth. Doctor: And, then, we’re going to skip Dr. S_’s appointment on April sixteenth, and then we’ll just follow with me subsequently. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, um, um, Patient: By then, I will have had my – Doctor: I think you can get your hormone shot.

Patient: Dr. F_____. Doctor: Dr. F_____ is a radiation doc- Family Member: Oh. Doctor: -so you’ll need a med onc doc like me. Family Member: Ohh, I forgot about that. so doctor connect or somebody up that way. Doctor: See someone up that way. Family Member: Is there even someone up that way even? I mean, I don't know. Doctor: I think so. Family Member: I think Dr. F_____. Doctor: They kind of go out like, yeah, there's somebody that's out there like once a week or once a month, they rotate. Family Member: So they come out and do infusions? Doctor: No, I think the infusion people are there all the time. I think the doctors come out every so often. Family Member: Ohh. Okay.

Healthcare Professional 1: So did you make another appointment to see Dr. G____? Patient: Yeah uh uhhh… Doctor: Okay so they gave you enough? Patient: I think she said March – March, March something, March twenty-third or something. Doctor: Okay, alright. Patient: Twenty-second, twenty-third. Doctor: Let’s see what he finds. Okay so… Patient: I hope he don’t find nothing.
DOC Well good point. (Laughs) Doctor: This is your copy of the chemo consent. Okay? Alright so go over and we’ll go ahead with your treatment and you got all your scripts then. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Healthcare Professional 1: Everything else went electronically other that what you have in your hand. Okay?

Patient: Right. Doctor: Especially, when we are starting you on a medicine that could Patient: Right, can Doctor: Worsen your blood pressure. I may need to adjust it further. Patient: Okay. How about like walking for extended, like, two to three mile walks, is that, is that alright? Doctor: It’s play it by ear as to how much you are hurting. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, I’m planning on getting scans next week and seeing Patient: Okay. Doctor: You anyway. So, within a week or two, I’ll be able to tell you. Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: What we are doing. Okay. The Zytiga, now this is a very specialized medication because it’s for cancer. Okay. So, we will need to send it to a mail order pharmacy. There are these specialty pharmacies

Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me? Doctor: Okay. Patient: I need that, too. I don’t have a primary care doctor right now. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m ‘ppossed to, ‘pposed to go see one of the Wayne State guys next Thursday. Doctor: Yeah, because one day I’m gonna assign you somebody or something, and then your insurance changed? Patient: No, that one over there, I didn’t. That’s why I told them I didn’t want to come back over there no more. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I didn’t… they didn’t impress me. I mean, they fine (laughs) Doctor: Don’t tell me. They didn’t yell at you enough? Doctor: Okay. Patient: It’s south for you and I’m gonna start going there. Doctor: Okay, but I’ll send it in because I don’t want you to run around with high blood pressure either.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Not through the antigen receptor, which is all those IT doesn’t expand these but a completely different way to shut down the cell. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, but you have to figure out where you are in that trial. So the first thing she needs to do is be able to test your specimens for this particular marker. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So that’s the first thing. The second thing is that if we do get you on, probably the top three side effects would be tiredness. Patient: Hmm, I’m an expert on that. Patient: Yeah, fortunately you know - Doctor: Mm hmm and you weren’t too bad. Patient: You know being a retiree, Doctor: Yeah, Patient: I mean I can sleep.

Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything” Patient: Yeah I quit Lupron for that reason. Doctor: And you're just like, oh, man, I can't do it. Patient: So, what was the other doctor’s name? Doctor: J____. Family Member: J____. Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Like a while ago or recent? Patient: Probably a year ago, I’m guessing. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh, full body, full body MRI? Doctor: No. That site. Because you had the back issue. You do have a nice amount of arthritis as I recall and disk issues there. But, does that seem like it’s the same pain or is it a different pain? Patient: No. It seems to mirror what I was experiencing before. Doctor: Because I think between now and the six weeks that stuffs coming out of you, you decide whether, you know, if it’s looking like even week three of our six-week little holiday here, you go, yeah, you know what, this stuff’s really not getting any better. You call us. We’ll just order the MRI. Poof. Done. Family Member: He’s supposed to see Dr. V___ in a couple of weeks. Doctor: Good. Good. Patient: I think it’s July second - Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - then there’s no question that hormone therapy will cause more side effects than radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: There’s no question about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, if your goal is to try to eradicate as much of the cancer as fast as possible – Family Member: Um hum. DOC - then the best way to do that although it’s still not a cure is hormone therapy plus or minus something else. So something new. Doctor: Right, so there’s no question that hormone therapy within the first three months is going to kill like ninety-nine percent of the cancer. Happens with almost everyone. With radiotherapy you know there’s a decent chance that it’s going to kill whatever cancer happens to be part that we radiate – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - but the rest of the cancer which is going to be invisible is obviously going to be outside of that radiation field. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: It’s not going to be touched. And the concern with that is although I am a proponent of someone that wants to – If your goal is absolutely to avoid hormone therapy as long as possible, that’s a good option for you. And again, what would be driving that would be more quality of life.

Patient: I lost five more pounds. I got to gain my weight back. Doctor: Well yeah you got to get your teeth back in. Patient: I’m going, I’m going, I’m making the appointment Thursday. I’m going and having them take these out of here. I don’t know, I might have to pay for some more because I don’t think my insurance will cover this, but I want – I’m gonna do it anyway. Doctor: See what they say. Meanwhile though I need you to be drinking those Ensure cans. Two to three a day. Patient: I got it your husband he wrote me a thing to go down there and get me two case. I’m gonna get a case of Ensure and Boost. Doctor: Good. Patient: But I’m gonna be eating and next time I come here… Doctor: Okay, good. Yeah. Patient: …I’m gonna have my weight is gonna grow back. Doctor: Alright. Good. I’m gonna hold you to it. Patient: And you know when I tell you something (laughs) Patient: You know that’s how it be doc you know that, you know that. Doctor: Okay so when did I last give you this uh medication? When are you going to go fill them?
